The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and highlights the significant events and leaders of the Civil Rights movement. It aims to preserve the first-hand memories and stories of those who participated in the movement. The Civil Rights movement participants possess valuable first-hand memories that should be recorded to provide a detailed history of the period. A project to collect oral histories is essential for future generations to learn about the struggle and sacrifice through primary-source material. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are suitable repositories for preserving and making available these oral histories. The purpose of this Act is to establish a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals who participated in the American Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution will coordinate this national project to preserve these memories for future generations. The Act establishes a joint project between the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture to collect video and audio recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights movement. The project aims to survey existing collections, avoid duplication of efforts, and gather reminiscences to preserve the history for future generations. The Act establishes a project to collect video and audio recordings of Civil Rights movement participants, gather personal histories and materials, create a collection, and make it available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Act establishes a project to collect video and audio recordings of Civil Rights movement participants, gather personal histories and materials, create a collection, and make it available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary shall carry out duties through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, and may consult with other entities and experts for the project. The Act allows for the procurement of services, utilization of volunteers, and making advance payments for the collection of video and audio recordings related to the Civil Rights movement. The term "Civil Rights movement" is defined as the movement for racial equality in the United States from 1954 to 1968. The Civil Rights movement aimed to secure racial equality in the United States for African Americans from 1954 to 1968, challenging racial segregation and achieving equal rights legislation. The Act encourages donations to support Civil Rights history projects and authorizes appropriations for these activities. SEC. 5.
